greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Decimal expansion of the prime zeta modulo function at 9 for primes of the form 4k+1.
link: Jean-François Alcover, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1009
X. Gourdon and P. Sebah, Some Constants from Number theory.
R. J. Mathar, Table of Dirichlet L-series and prime zeta modulo functions for small moduli, arXiv:1008.2547 [math.NT], 2010-2015, value P(m=4, n=1, s=9), page 21.
OEIS index to entries related to the (prime) zeta function.
formula: Zeta_Q(9) = Sum_{p in A002144} 1/p^9, where A002144 = {primes p == 1 mod 4};
= Sum_{odd m > 0} mu(m)/2m * log(DirichletBeta(9m)*zeta(9m)/zeta(18m)/(1 + 2^(-9m))) [using Gourdon & Sebah, Theorem 11]. - _M. F. Hasler_, Apr 26 2021
mathematica: nmax0 = 50; (* initial number of sum terms *)
PrimeZeta41[s_, nmax_] := PrimeZeta41[s, nmax] = (1/2) Sum[MoebiusMu[2 n + 1]*Log[f[(2 n + 1)*9]]/(2 n + 1), {n, 0, nmax}] // N[#, digits + dd&;
While[Abs[PrimeZeta41[9, nmax] - PrimeZeta41[9, nmax - dnmax]] > 10^-(digits + dd), Print["nmax = ", nmax]; nmax += dnmax];
Join[{0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0}, RealDigits[PrimeZeta41[9], 10, digits][[1]]] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jun 24 2011, after X. Gourdon and P. Sebah, updated May 07 2021 *)
program: (PARI) A086039_upto(N=100)={localprec(N+3); digits((PrimeZeta41(9)+1)\.1^N)[^1]} \\ see A086032 for the PrimeZeta41 function. - _M. F. Hasler_, Apr 26 2021
xref: Cf. A085998 (same for primes 4k+3), A343629 (for primes 3k+1), A343619 (for primes 3k+2), A086032 - A086038 (for 1/p^2, ..., 1/p^8), A085969 (PrimeZeta(9)), A002144 (primes of the form 4k+1).
results.author: Antonio G. Astudillo (afg_astudillo(AT)lycos.com), Jul 07 2003
